name: Microbiology Quiz - Chapter 25
description: Quiz questions for Chapter 25 of the OpenStax Microbiology textbook.
subject: Microbiology

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: The circulatory (or cardiovascular) system is a(n) ________________network of organs and vessels that moves blood around the body.
questions.explanation: The human circulatory system is a closed network, meaning the blood is contained within vessels.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following diseases is caused by a spirochete?
questions.explanation: Relapsing fever is caused by spirochetes of the genus Borrelia.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Despite more than a century of intense research and clinical advancements, ________________  remains one of the most important infectious diseases in the world today with approximately  _______________  million cases worldwide,
questions.explanation: Malaria remains a major global health problem, with an estimated 210 million cases worldwide.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Also called American trypanosomiasis, Chagas disease is a zoonosis classified as a neglected tropical disease (NTD). It is caused by the flagellated ______________________ Trypanosoma cruzi.
questions.explanation: Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which term refers to an inflammation of the blood vessels?
questions.explanation: Vasculitis is the general term for inflammation of the blood vessels.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of these viruses is spread through mouse urine or feces?
questions.explanation: Hantavirus is transmitted to humans through inhalation of aerosols from the urine, feces, and saliva of infected rodents.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is located in the interstitial spaces within tissues and releases nutrients, immune factors, and oxygen to those tissues?
questions.explanation: Capillaries are the smallest blood vessels and are the site of exchange of nutrients, waste, and oxygen with tissues at the cellular level.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: The lymphatic system is an  ___________ system with the fluid moving in one direction from the extremities toward two drainage points into veins just above the heart.
questions.explanation: The lymphatic system is an open system; lymph fluid is not contained within a closed loop of vessels.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of these conditions results in the formation of a bubo?
questions.explanation: Lymphadenitis, the inflammation of lymph nodes, can result in swollen, painful nodes called buboes, which is characteristic of bubonic plague.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is where are most microbes filtered out of the fluids that accumulate in the body tissues?
questions.explanation: Lymph nodes are major sites for filtering lymph and trapping foreign particles and microorganisms.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is a false statement?
options: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis.
Lyme disease always causes a bullâ€™s eye rash.
Malaria is caused by a protozoan parasite, most commonly Plasmodium falciparum.
Prophylactic antibiotic treatment is sometimes used for those at high risk of developing recurrent rheumatic fever.
questions.explanation: The characteristic bull's-eye rash (erythema migrans) of Lyme disease does not appear in all cases.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: What is the best definition for viremia?
options: bacteria are present in the blood
viruses are present in the blood
toxins are present in the blood
bacteria are reproducing in the blood
questions.explanation: Viremia is the presence of viruses in the blood.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by body lice?
questions.explanation: Epidemic typhus is transmitted by the human body louse.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of medication used to treat HIV?
options: medications that prevent the virus from entering cells
medications that block HIV replication enzymes
medications that block RNA-dependent DNA polymerases
questions.explanation: HIV medications work by interfering with the viral life cycle, such as blocking entry or replication enzymes. Denaturing the virus is not a mechanism of antiretroviral drugs.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Maya spends a day hiking in the woods then finds a tick on her skin that evening. Could the tick have transmitted Lyme disease?
options: No, because Lyme disease is not transmitted by ticks.
Yes, because any contact with an infected tick is sufficient to transmit Lyme disease.
No, because the tick was not attached for at least 24 hours.
Yes, because the tick was probably attached for more than 4 hours.
questions.explanation: Transmission of Lyme disease is unlikely if the tick is attached for less than 24 hours.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: What disease is most associated with Clostridium perfringens?
questions.explanation: Clostridium perfringens is the primary causative agent of gas gangrene.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which bacterial pathogen causes plague?
questions.explanation: Plague is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following viruses is most widespread in the human population?
questions.explanation: Epstein-Barr virus is one of the most common human viruses, with a majority of the world's population being infected at some point in their lives.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: A patient at a clinic has tested positive for HIV. Her blood contained 700/ÂµL CD4 T cells and she does not have any apparent illness. Her infection is in which stage?
questions.explanation: Stage 1 of HIV infection is characterized by a CD4 T-cell count of 500 cells/ÂµL or greater and no AIDS-defining conditions.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: An individual is suspected of having malaria on the basis of clinical symptoms. Which steps should a medical professional take to confirm and treat a malaria diagnosis?
options: serological tests followed by treatment with stibogluconate or amphotericin B
PCR followed by treatment with nifurtimox or benznidazole
microscopic analysis of a blood smear and/or enzyme immunoassay followed by treatment with chloroquine, artemether, atovaquone, or lumefantrine
microscopic analysis of a blood smear and staining, followed by treatment with azithromycin, doxycycline, or tetracycline.
questions.explanation: The standard for malaria diagnosis is microscopic examination of a blood smear, and treatment typically involves drugs like chloroquine or artemisinin-based combination therapies.
